E372DF3B45F5434E84C5DCFCEB5B97F7.description: SSPH.A.16.g: draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

9F69437971D448D385D82A029F709CE1.description: SSPH.A.16.f: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

5ED65E13577D4A2988E2DB46BEBF2CF5.description: SSPH.A.16.e: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

C9F82B0C75C74E75ABD383DAB9AC09C0.description: SSPH.A.16.d: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

1E745C53A42649AE97CB75EC72BA9189.description: SSPH.A.16.b: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

A97A9634B039491EA32DCC33FFA49D03.description: SSPH.A.6.q: write routinely over extended time frames (time for reflection and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences

93FD1CD0D18C49618DB09DBF35781BBC.description: SSPH.A.6.p: draw evidence from informational texts to support analysis, reflection, and research

9186BD726CA946F1A0495BF51A721684.description: SSPH.A.6.o: gather relevant information from multiple authoritative print and digital sources, using advanced searches effectively; assess the strengths and limitations of each source in terms of the specific task, purpose, and audience; integrate information into the text selectively to maintain the flow of ideas, avoiding plagiarism and overreliance on any one source and following a standard format for citation

413F3F79913E4B588917D695E7168072.description: SSPH.A.6.n: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

3F9065E712944E44B73924D560E645C7.description: SSPH.A.6.m: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

02C3EA5B2B4246EC9DF32621040D512C.description: SSPH.A.6.l: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

75B72C630C054BF88B44D423A509653B.description: SSPH.A.6.k: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

3ABEDC9D7E174B6B8E4ED29A3D827FBB.description: SSPH.A.6.j: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

C98121E8D4EC412C9BDBAAE1E809A10F.description: SSPH.A.6.i: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

A7E528BCC74B4288835D472828BEC497.description: SSPH.A.6.h: by the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11-12 text complexity band independently and proficiently

6C838451EA9E4414BD7D0B1E945FE825.description: SSPH.A.6.g: integrate information from diverse sources, both primary and secondary, into a coherent understanding of an idea or event, noting discrepancies among sources

0A53571C79714A499D6D02B42B93C65F.description: SSPH.A.6.f: evaluate an author's premises, claims, and evidence by corroborating or challenging them with other information

E4C0954EE32B4C5D95AAD44EBD383EA6.description: SSPH.A.6.e: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, as well as in words) in order to address a question or solve a problem

66AC0E1276924A3BA417375AD1BFB693.description: SSPH.A.6.d: analyze in detail how a complex primary source is structured, including how key sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text contribute to the whole

C4C0F56026B54450952013A9AFA067CA.description: SSPH.A.6.c: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including analyzing how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term over the course of a text

16EE0CBE49E04790BA9C2F20D2B0A26D.description: SSPH.A.6.b: determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary that makes clear the relationships among the key details and ideas

D57AC45DD3D44D688D7453EE94775A6F.description: SSPH.A.6.a: cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources, connecting insights gained from specific details to an understanding of the text as a whole

B579C4B82A8D4D37B506A65931324487.description: SSPH.A.6: identify and use primary and secondary sources

345E497C771341B1BCBA49F6F427F251.description: SSPH.A.5.r: write routinely over extended time frames (time for reflection and revision) and shorter time frames (a single sitting or a day or two) for a range of discipline-specific tasks, purposes, and audiences

DFA12D3D14B14CC1A9469A4E4E13DECF.description: SSPH.A.5.q: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

3B2F105921CF4026A7E8A14EEDA1DB78.description: SSPH.A.5.p: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

E0F62B00E4E146FCAB9E631915D6487E.description: SSPH.A.5.o: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

64FA8EFEEABC44478F454C23CE92E4E6.description: SSPH.A.5.n: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

460AC06B285E485F9C2240B0765D8AE6.description: SSPH.A.5.m: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using precise language, domain-specific vocabulary and techniques such as metaphor, simile, and analogy to manage the complexity of the topic; conveying a knowledgeable stance in a style that responds to the discipline and context as well as to the expertise of likely readers

342E19A77BA747368A59563BF702CAA5.description: SSPH.A.5.l: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by using varied transitions and sentence structures to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships among complex ideas and concepts

60708BACB6DE46C4828FAEA5C4822AF7.description: SSPH.A.5.k: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by developing the topic thoroughly by selecting the most significant and relevant facts, extended definitions, concrete details, quotations, or other information and examples appropriate to the audience's knowledge of the topic

E15997CCAB084507B26B43347242BEBC.description: SSPH.A.5.j: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by introducing a topic and organizing complex ideas, concepts, and information so that each new element builds on that which precedes it to create a unified whole; including formatting (e.g., headings), graphics (e.g., figures, tables), and multimedia when useful to aiding comprehension

EE981349B3A04AACA0A49885E4279380.description: SSPH.A.5.i: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from or supports the argument presented

A7D3973C2662499998A87E056B3F583C.description: SSPH.A.5.h: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by establishing and maintaining a formal style and objective tone while attending to the norms and conventions of the discipline in which they are writing

A89752081E8E40A89FDB9BC5E7382840.description: SSPH.A.5.g: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by using words, phrases, and clauses as well as varied syntax to link the major sections of the text, creating cohesion, and clarifying the relationships between claim(s) and reasons, between reasons and evidence, and between claim(s) and counterclaims

2634FBA4181C4862A1A06BF01D161DF6.description: SSPH.A.5.f: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by developing claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant data and evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both claim(s) and counterclaims in a discipline-appropriate form that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases

B79F0E4A9E93416DB80A0353990EDAD3.description: SSPH.A.5.e: by the end of grade 12, read and comprehend history/social studies texts in the grades 11-12 text complexity band independently and proficiently

9B5C4541145B40D5B68A8A5F418A825C.description: SSPH.A.5.d: analyze in detail how a complex primary source is structured, including how key sentences, paragraphs, and larger portions of the text contribute to the whole

86D605F9F3A340B89D4D273249216F31.description: SSPH.A.5.c: determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including analyzing how an author uses and refines the meaning of a key term over the course of a text

99F5194399574958826C9375836DDB35.description: SSPH.A.5.b: evaluate various explanations for actions or events and determine which explanation best accords with textual evidence, acknowledging where the text leaves matters uncertain

871A52BCC45A487BA26068AD5D504AA4.description: SSPH.A.5.a: determine the central ideas or information of a primary or secondary source; provide an accurate summary that makes clear the relationships among the key details and ideas

D3E327CEB8BA44768B08476DC07E3717.description: SSPH.A.5: identify main idea, detail, sequence of events and cause and effect in a social studies context

9D761C5E5E264B4292CA7E9D5E5902F5.description: SSPH.A.4.i: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

81477DF79F064D41B6EB6A97C7056C53.description: SSPH.A.4.h: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

5A7BA06A5511445693F5ADFC45FEC651.description: SSPH.A.4.g: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

030528EBC64249D08AC420F1CCBBD1AE.description: SSPH.A.4.f: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation provided (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic)

90FEEBB52DDF46CD82E00E2DEEB75376.description: SSPH.A.4.e: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by developing claim(s) and counterclaims fairly and thoroughly, supplying the most relevant data and evidence for each while pointing out the strengths and limitations of both claim(s) and counterclaims in a discipline-appropriate form that anticipates the audience's knowledge level, concerns, values, and possible biases

1EBCB70421C648D1AFD72112CDB01260.description: SSPH.A.4.d: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by introducing precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establishing the significance of the claim(s), distinguishing the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and creating an organization that logically sequences the claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence

75C8A97252C540219A62BCA804F0848D.description: SSPH.A.4.c: integrate information from diverse sources, both primary and secondary, into a coherent understanding of an idea or event, noting discrepancies among sources

D6583997C25C474C967677CA65F92D74.description: SSPH.A.4.b: evaluate an author's premises, claims, and evidence by corroborating or challenging them with other information

A4568064F82D4FB8AC03DCA0783B3047.description: SSPH.A.4.a: integrate and evaluate multiple sources of information presented in diverse formats and media (e.g., visually, quantitatively, as well as in words) in order to address a question or solve a problem

218FDEAD3F25447EBDDD583153FBDF54.description: SSPH.A.4: distinguish between fact and opinion as used in informational/explanatory text

8D1AFAB67B6142A8B8F31A9518C7DD07.description: SSPH.A.3.f: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

5DB305391A1742C9ABF46B03B5E0052F.description: SSPH.A.3.e: use technology, including the Internet, to produce, publish, and update individual or shared writing products in response to ongoing feedback, including new arguments or information

F507429A1E9E489BAF79340659E3FAE1.description: SSPH.A.3.d: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

1B16D54839F248999017C8466DD5ED46.description: SSPH.A.3.c: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

9C97E37513C04710B6781DA1F66AECA5.description: SSPH.A.3.b: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation provided (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic)

F6EA8ADD941E4775AA4FB4B15E84829F.description: SSPH.A.3.a: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from or supports the argument presented

F8FB8D30FF644368AF6CE2188FCE5370.description: SSPH.A.3: identify and write about issues and/or problems and alternative solutions

F29600DC6BC14CDB8608F289C5A324CD.description: SSPH.A.2.c: develop and strengthen writing as needed by planning, revising, editing, rewriting, or trying a new approach, focusing on addressing what is most significant for a specific purpose and audience

B99F380A0CB44217BAB86D9204132CFB.description: SSPH.A.2.b: produce clear and coherent writing in which the development, organization, and style are appropriate to task, purpose, and audience

0B56C2016E654318A33DCC833701A7CF.description: SSPH.A.2.a: cite specific textual evidence to support analysis of primary and secondary sources, connecting insights gained from specific details to an understanding of the text as a whole

ADC3309232B04B669F1D3E2702091801.description: SSPH.A.1.d: conduct short as well as more sustained research projects to answer a question (including a self-generated question) or solve a problem; narrow or broaden the inquiry when appropriate; synthesize multiple sources on the subject, demonstrating understanding of the subject under investigation

B8BFCB5EBF24435EB1DAB97C369D6A14.description: SSPH.A.1.c: write informative/explanatory texts, including the narration of historical events by providing a concluding statement or section that follows from and supports the information or explanation provided (e.g., articulating implications or the significance of the topic)

A28E5F99E2B641A9A769BAA780B0AFE0.description: SSPH.A.1.a: write arguments focused on discipline-specific content by introducing precise, knowledgeable claim(s), establishing the significance of the claim(s), distinguishing the claim(s) from alternate or opposing claims, and creating an organization that logically sequences the claim(s), counterclaims, reasons, and evidence
